questions.prompt: In BG 7.1, what principle does Krishna ask Arjuna to do?
choices: Leave battlefield through independent material engagement processes
Hear about knowledge and entirely surrender to Krishna
Study scriptures alone through independent material speculation
Perform rituals through worldly philosophical speculation only
questions.feedback: Krishna reveals the knowledge of self and His divine nature through complete surrender and hearing. The verse emphasizes yoga with attachment to Krishna (mayi asakta-manah), not independent philosophical speculation. The trap is attempting spiritual understanding through detached intellectual analysis rather than devotional connection. Real knowledge comes through relationship with the Supreme, combining theoretical understanding with devotional practice.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 7.2, what false path does Srila Prabhupada warn against regarding spiritual knowledge?
choices: Pursuing intellectual understanding without practical realization through devotional service engagement
Reading too many books instead of focusing on single scripture study alone
Seeking knowledge from spiritual teachers rather than discovering independently through speculation
Studying philosophy before establishing firm foundation in ritual worship practices
questions.feedback: Srila Prabhupada explains that theoretical knowledge alone is insufficient. One must combine jnana (knowledge) with vijnana (realized understanding) through practice. The trap is accumulating information without transformation. Why this matters: Modern seekers confuse intellectual grasp with actual realization. The false path is studying endlessly without applying knowledge in devotional practice.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 7.3, what distinction does Srila Prabhupada make between jnana and vijnana?
choices: Jnana is theoretical knowledge; vijnana is realized practical understanding
Jnana comes from books; vijnana comes from direct guru instruction
Jnana is intellectual understanding; vijnana is emotional devotional feeling
Jnana means material knowledge; vijnana means transcendental scriptural study
questions.feedback: Srila Prabhupada explains that jnana means theoretical knowledge of the spirit soul's nature. Vijnana means practical realization of spiritual truth through devotional practice. The trap: collecting information without transformation. Why this matters: The false path is academic study without applying Krishna consciousness in life. Real spiritual advancement requires both theoretical understanding and practical realization.

questions.prompt: What does BG 7.4 teach about Krishna's energies?
choices: Krishna has no power through speculative material processes
My energy divides into eight aspects manifesting all beings
Everything is one through speculative material processes only
Only one primary energy exists through material speculation
questions.feedback: The Lord manifests the material and spiritual worlds through His eight-fold separated energy: earth, water, fire, air, ether, mind, intelligence, and false ego. These are Krishna's inferior energy (apara prakriti). The psychological insight: we mistake the energy for the energetic source. The trap is studying the manifestation while ignoring the origin. Understanding the elements as Krishna's energy prevents materialistic reduction of reality to mere matter.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 7.5, what false conception does Srila Prabhupada warn against about the living entity?
choices: That living entities are simply combinations of material elements only
That souls gradually evolve from matter through biological processes over time
That consciousness emerges from complex chemical reactions in the brain
That individual souls will eventually merge into one impersonal existence
questions.feedback: Srila Prabhupada warns against the materialistic view that life comes from matter. The living entity is superior energy, not a product of inferior material combinations. The trap: thinking consciousness is material byproduct. Why this matters: The false path is reducing spiritual to material. Real understanding recognizes the soul as eternally distinct from matter.

questions.prompt: In BG 7.6, what is the origin of all beings?
choices: All beings are eternal through independent material processes
I am the source of everything that exists
Matter created itself through independent material processes
Beings created randomly through independent material processes
questions.feedback: Krishna is the ultimate source and sustainer of all existence - both the origin and dissolution of the entire universe. The verse states 'aham krtsnasya jagatah prabhavah' (I am the source of all this world) and 'pralayah' (dissolution). The trap is accepting cosmic evolution without acknowledging the conscious source. Why this matters: Recognizing Krishna as both origin and end prevents the materialistic error of thinking matter creates itself through random processes.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 7.7, what psychological trap does Srila Prabhupada identify about perceiving the Absolute?
choices: Thinking the Absolute must be impersonal because personal form suggests material limitation
Believing that God's form must conform to our material imagination and expectations
Assuming the Absolute can be fully understood through logical reasoning and philosophy
Concluding that all paths lead to same destination regardless of actual understanding
questions.feedback: Srila Prabhupada warns against the impersonalist error - thinking that personality implies material limitation. This is the mayavadi trap: projecting material defects onto the spiritual realm. Why this matters: The false path is rejecting Krishna's personal form while claiming to be advanced. Real knowledge accepts the Absolute Truth as simultaneously personal and unlimited.

questions.prompt: According to BG 7.8, what principle does Krishna identify as His living energy?
choices: Matter alone through worldly material speculation
The sound vibration OM representing spiritual energy
Time alone through worldly material speculation
Space alone through worldly material speculation
questions.feedback: The sacred sound OM (pranava sarva-vedeshu) represents Krishna's transcendental potency in all the Vedas. Krishna is also the taste in water, the light of sun and moon, the syllable OM, sound in ether, and ability in man. The teaching: Krishna pervades creation not as impersonal force but as the essential quality that makes each thing what it is. The psychological insight is recognizing the personal presence of the Supreme in ordinary experience.

questions.prompt: In BG 7.9, what are examples of Krishna being the original of all?
choices: Krishna is present primarily only in formal temple worship and rituals
I am fragrance in earth, heat in fire, life in all living beings
Examples of Krishna's presence cannot be given through speculative material processes
Only minimal qualities come from Krishna through independent material speculation
questions.feedback: Krishna is perceptible through His intimate presence in all creation: the original fragrance of earth, the brilliance in fire, the life in all living beings, and the austerity in ascetics. This verse teaches practical Krishna consciousness - perceiving the divine in immediate sensory experience. The trap is relegating God to abstract philosophy while missing His presence in daily life. Real spiritual vision means recognizing Krishna as the essential principle behind all perceptible qualities.

questions.prompt: What does BG 7.10 teach about Krishna's powers?
choices: Krishna has no power through speculative material processes
Force of energy is essence, everything rests on my potency
Power is only temporary through speculative material processes
Only one primary thing has power in material existence
questions.feedback: Krishna's energy is the fundamental basis of all material and spiritual existence. He is the original seed of all beings and the intelligence of the intelligent. The verse emphasizes that strength, power, and desire free from lust all rest on Krishna's potency. Why this matters: This prevents the secular error of thinking human capacities are self-generated. Real understanding recognizes that all abilities flow from the Supreme source, fostering humility rather than false pride in personal accomplishment.

questions.prompt: According to BG 7.11, how does Krishna manifest in the world?
choices: Only in temples through formal worship and ritualistic ceremonies alone
As strength of strong devoid of passion and dharmic desire
In nature alone through independent material processes without any purpose
Through intellectual speculation and philosophical debate exclusively without devotion
questions.feedback: Krishna is the strength of the strong devoid of passion and desire, and He is sex life not contrary to dharma (religious principles). This verse reveals how Krishna manifests in regulated human activities. The teaching: strength should protect the weak, not serve personal aggression. Sex life under dharma propagates Krishna conscious children. Why this matters: The trap is thinking spiritual life means abandoning all material activities. Real spiritual advancement sanctifies material existence through dharmic regulation rather than artificial renunciation.

questions.prompt: In BG 7.12, what is Krishna's relationship to the modes of material nature?
choices: Krishna is controlled by the three modes like all other beings
All modes emanate from Krishna, but He remains transcendent to them
The modes exist independently without any connection to Krishna
Krishna identifies Himself completely with the mode of goodness
questions.feedback: All states of being in goodness, passion, and ignorance emanate from Krishna's energy, yet He is not in them - they are in Him. Krishna remains nirguna (beyond the modes). The psychological insight: the modes condition us, but Krishna orchestrates them without being bound. Why this matters: The false path is thinking material qualities affect the Supreme. Real understanding recognizes that while we are influenced by the modes of nature, Krishna transcends them completely, like a king who makes laws but is not subject to them.

questions.prompt: What does BG 7.13 teach about those attached to material desires?
choices: They progress spiritually through independent material processes
They worship demigods seeking temporary material rewards
Everyone gains equally through independent material processes
Material desire is good through independent material processes
questions.feedback: Those caught in material desires achieve only temporary material rewards. This verse (7.13) reveals that the entire world, deluded by the three modes (tribhir guna-mayair bhavair), does not know Krishna as transcendental and inexhaustible. The trap is being so absorbed in the interplay of material qualities that one never questions their source. Real intelligence pierces through the modes to recognize the transcendent controller behind nature's machinery.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 7.14, why does Srila Prabhupada warn that maya is insurmountable by material effort?
choices: Because maya actively prevents all spiritual progress through constant material engagement
Because only surrender to Krishna provides the power to overcome maya's illusion
Because maya requires many lifetimes of gradual purification before transcendence
Because maya is ultimately more powerful than God's grace and divine mercy
questions.feedback: Srila Prabhupada explains that maya is daivi (divine) and cannot be overcome by personal effort. Only by surrendering to Krishna does one cross over. The psychological trap is thinking self-improvement alone can achieve liberation. Why this matters: The false path is attempting spiritual advancement through willpower without devotion. Real transcendence requires grace through surrender.

questions.prompt: In BG 7.15, what types of fools are mentioned?
choices: Only the ignorant through independent material processes
Those who know not my transcendental divine nature
All people are wise through independent material processes
Knowledge brings problems through independent material processes
questions.feedback: Ignoring Krishna's nature is the greatest folly and waste of human life. The verse identifies four types of miscreants who never surrender: the foolish, the lowest of mankind, those whose knowledge is stolen by illusion, and those of demonic nature. Why this matters: The false path is thinking ignorance of God is neutral or harmless. Real understanding recognizes that rejecting the Supreme is active self-deception with catastrophic spiritual consequences. Intelligence means using the human form to reestablish our relationship with Krishna.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 7.16, what warning does Srila Prabhupada give about approaching God with material desires?
choices: That any approach to God, even with desires, is completely worthless and condemned
That distressed and desiring devotees are pious but must eventually seek pure love
That only those approaching without any motivation whatsoever can be accepted
That material desires automatically disqualify one from any spiritual progress completely
questions.feedback: Srila Prabhupada explains that approaching Krishna even with material desires is pious, but the highest platform is seeking Krishna without expectation. The trap is either rejecting conditional devotees or remaining stuck in material motivation. Why this matters: The false path is thinking impure motivation prevents spiritual life. Real progress allows gradual purification from material desires to pure love.

questions.prompt: According to BG 7.17, among those who approach Krishna, who is dearest to Him?
choices: The distressed through worldly philosophical speculation
The wise serving me with single-pointed devotion
The wealthy through worldly philosophical speculation
The powerful through worldly philosophical speculation
questions.feedback: The sincere devotee devoted to Krishna alone is most beloved. Among the four types who approach Krishna (distressed, seeker of wealth, inquisitive, and wise), the jnani (wise one) in constant union with Krishna through pure devotion is dearest. The contrast: all four are pious, but the jnani transcends conditional motivation. The trap is remaining stuck in approaching God for relief or gain rather than for love itself. Real maturity evolves from self-interest to selfless devotion.

questions.prompt: In BG 7.18-19, who are truly wise according to Krishna?
choices: The learned scholars who understand through speculative material processes
After many births, wise know me as everything that is
Material scholars are wisest who study through speculative processes
No one is truly wise who relies on speculative material processes
questions.feedback: True wisdom culminates in surrender to the Supreme. After many births of philosophical searching (bahunam janmanam ante), one who truly knows surrenders to Krishna, understanding that Vasudeva is all. The psychological insight: intellectual seeking must eventually conclude in devotional surrender. The trap is perpetual philosophical speculation without reaching conclusion. Why this matters: The false path treats spiritual inquiry as endless academic pursuit. Real knowledge recognizes when the search must transform into relationship.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 7.19, what false conception does Srila Prabhupada address about spiritual advancement?
choices: That anyone can achieve full realization quickly through weekend meditation retreats
That after many births of seeking, the wise person recognizes Krishna as everything
That spiritual knowledge develops automatically without sustained practice or study
That material advancement and wealth indicate spiritual progress and divine favor
questions.feedback: Srila Prabhupada explains that after many births of philosophical search, one who truly knows surrenders to Krishna, recognizing Vasudeva as all. The psychological insight: intellectual seeking eventually must culminate in devotional surrender. Why this matters: The false path is perpetual philosophical speculation without conclusion. Real wisdom recognizes Krishna as the ultimate goal after exhausting material alternatives.

questions.prompt: According to BG 7.21, what happens when Krishna grants desires to other deities' worshippers?
choices: Krishna denies them completely through speculative material processes only
I grant desires, but they eventually return to material world
They achieve complete liberation through speculative material processes entirely
They prosper forever eternally through speculative material processes constantly
questions.feedback: Material desires may be fulfilled but lead only to temporary satisfaction. The verse (7.21) teaches that when one worships demigods with faith, Krishna actually grants the results. However, such worshipers of small intelligence go to the demigods, while Krishna's devotees come to Him. Why this matters: The trap is seeking immediate material solutions while sacrificing the eternal goal. Real intelligence directs worship to the Supreme who can grant both temporary and permanent benefits, rather than settling for temporary gains from lesser beings.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 7.20-23, what psychological trap does Srila Prabhupada identify about demigod worship?
choices: That demigods are completely imaginary and worshiping them produces no results
That worship of demigods brings temporary rewards but distracts from ultimate goal
That demigod worship is equally valuable as Krishna worship for spiritual liberation
That demigods are more accessible than Krishna and therefore better for beginners
questions.feedback: Srila Prabhupada warns that those of small intelligence worship demigods for temporary material benefits, missing the supreme goal. The trap is being satisfied with lesser attainments. Why this matters: The false path is seeking material solutions from demigods while neglecting Krishna. Real intelligence directs worship to the Supreme Source who can grant both material and spiritual perfection.

questions.prompt: How do BG 7.4-5 and 7.14 work together to explain why surrendering to Krishna is the only way to transcend maya?
choices: Material energy is weak, so anyone can overcome it through willpower and determination
Maya (material energy) is Krishna's divine potency and insurmountable except by surrendering to Him
The living entities are products of material energy and have no independent existence
Material and spiritual energies are equal, so one can choose either path freely
questions.feedback: This synthesis reveals the paradox of spiritual life: maya (Krishna's inferior energy) is divine and insurmountable by material effort, yet Krishna's superior energy (the living entities) can transcend it through surrender. The living entity is superior to matter but inferior to Krishna. Why this matters: The false path is attempting self-improvement without grace. The psychological trap is pride in personal effort. Real transcendence recognizes that only by connecting to the Supreme through surrender can the soul overcome the divine illusion. This explains why Chapter 6's yoga requires devotion, not just technique.

questions.prompt: According to BG 7.25, why do foolish people mistake Krishna for a mortal?
choices: It is obvious Krishna is mortal being
They cannot understand my transcendental divine nature
Everyone knows Krishna's nature through material processes
This does not happen through independent material processes
questions.feedback: Ignorance of Krishna's divine nature is the cause of this delusion. The verse (7.25) explains that Krishna is not manifest to everyone, being covered by His yoga-maya potency. The foolish cannot understand the unborn, imperishable Supreme. The psychological insight: Krishna reveals Himself to devotees but remains hidden from those who reject Him. The trap is thinking Krishna is obligated to reveal Himself to our speculation. Real understanding comes through devotional surrender, not intellectual prowess alone.

questions.prompt: How does the progression from distressed/desiring devotees (BG 7.16) to wise devotees (7.17-19) illustrate the purification of motivation in spiritual life?
choices: All devotees must start with pure love; those with material desires are disqualified completely
Material motivation gradually purifies through devotional contact until one recognizes Krishna as everything
The four types of devotees remain forever separate with no possibility of advancement
Only philosophical study without devotional practice can transform material into spiritual understanding
questions.feedback: This synthesis reveals the dynamic nature of bhakti: the distressed and desiring are pious for approaching Krishna, but the goal is the jnani who serves with pure devotion. After many births, such a wise soul recognizes Vasudeva as all. The progression shows: (1) Material motivation is acceptable starting point, (2) Continued association purifies desires, (3) Wisdom culminates in seeing Krishna as everything. Why this matters: The false path is either rejecting beginners or remaining satisfied with conditional devotion. Real spiritual life is transformative - we can begin with mixed motives but must allow Krishna to purify us into pure lovers. This connects to Chapter 6's teaching that yoga perfection requires abandoning material desires (6.24).

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 7.25, why does Srila Prabhupada explain that Krishna is not manifest to everyone?
choices: Because Krishna randomly chooses favorites and conceals Himself from all others arbitrarily
Because Krishna is covered by yoga-maya and foolish people cannot understand Him properly
Because Krishna lacks the power to reveal Himself to materialistic people lacking devotion
Because people must achieve specific realization levels through effort before seeing Krishna
questions.feedback: Srila Prabhupada explains that Krishna is covered by His internal yoga-maya potency. Foolish people who do not surrender cannot understand Him. The psychological insight: Krishna reveals Himself to devotees but remains hidden from those who reject Him. Why this matters: The false path is thinking Krishna is bound to reveal Himself to our speculation. Real understanding comes through devotional surrender, not intellectual prowess.
